question: Some people think certain prisoners should be made to set up unpaid community work, instead of just being put behid the bars. To what extent do you agree or disagree?
text: Nowadays, it has been suggested that the role of community work can be a more beneficial alternative for the criminals to help them amend. Yet, there remains a contentious debate as to whether can the overall efficiency of this phenomenon be a more influential process rather than jail time. I partially agree with this topic and will support my perspective with more details and practical examples.

Firstly, the environment of the prisons can have detrimental impacts on the individual. In addition, it is an indisputable fact that being behind bars means spending time with dangerous people in a  toxic situation resulting in more harm than benefits for the person since this situation can undermine ethical codes for the prisoner; also, he or she would enter to other types of crimes and sins. For instance, a human who is passing custodial sentences will find the motivation to start drug dealing or murder which is a potent element of increasing the crime rate  in  society. Consequently, spending life in the cage is an effective factor in destroying the harmony of  a homogeneous nation, while the person can be altered to be a high potential offender for  societal security.

Further and even more importantly, though, the criminal is not able to revise his or her behaviour in this period. Regarding the fact that jail time is supposed to help the individual to refine himself or herself, it does not entail a safe condition for the criminal to learn from the mistake; on the other hand, community work can be a significant process for social awareness and can reintroduce the criminal to the society. One particularly salient example is a driving ticket for Overspeed that can be punished with short-term public cleanings; it can be both educating and profitable for  people to learn from their mistakes. Thus, community work is an effective solution to prevent  future crimes and teach the person of possible consequences of the crime.

As a way of conclusion, I once again reaffirm that spending time behind bars is a highly preventive suggestion for some criminals; nonetheless, for some specific scenarios, it can be replaced with community works to both keep the balance of  society and punish the person. Also, it is highly suggested to have cognitive processes for the youngsters to hinder them from various crimes before committing them .
